entry.title: Combined summary - Bitcoin-development Digest, Vol 48, Issue 41
entry.summary: The email thread among Bitcoin developers primarily discusses various aspects of Bitcoin development, including the block size increase, transaction security, and softfork signaling. The discussion on increasing the block size centers on Gavin's 20MB proposal, with Aaron Voisine supporting it to avoid negatively impacting user experience. Damian Gomez suggests that a higher rate than the current standard of 92 bytes could allow for GPUs to mechanize a new personal identity within the chain. The email thread also covers potential solutions to the low transactions per second (tps) problem, such as encouraging users to pay higher fees in the future and creating transactions with an expiration time starting with a low fee. There is a suggestion to use DH algorithm keys for increased system integrity, and a proposal to implement a Merkle-Winternitz OTS to prevent the loss of fee structure and enable one-way transactions to continue following the TESLA protocol. Concerns about man-in-the-middle attacks are raised, with solutions proposed such as keeping the block size under 300 bytes and adding encryption standards to the blockchain. Raystonn proposes replace-by-fee as a better approach to zombie transactions, but acknowledges the potential for huge fee spikes or a return to zombie transactions if fee caps are implemented by wallets. Mark Friedenbach notes that replace-by-fee is no longer reorg-safe because transactions can expire during a reorg, invalidating any transaction built on an expired transaction. Finally, Raystonn proposes an alternative feature that expires a transaction after a specific time, but acknowledges that time can be unreliable in the blockchain.Overall, the email thread highlights potential solutions and concerns regarding the block size increase in Bitcoin while maintaining the system's integrity and preventing interception of bundled information and the replacement of value.
